You can either showcase your apples at the festival’s community stand, building goodwill and local pride if you both participate, or you can withhold your best apples to try for a larger recognition and private prize at the exclusive tasting contest. If only one of you holds back, the one saving their apples gains all the personal accolades and the other is left in the background. If both of you hold back, the festival fizzles and neither earns much beyond ordinary involvement.

description: You and Bob are regulars at Willow Lake, each hoping for a great catch during trout season. Park rangers recently set a daily limit to protect the lake's ecosystem, but it's easy to keep a few extra fish when no one is watching. If both of you stick to the posted limit, the lake stays stocked and fishing remains rewarding. If one secretly keeps extra trout, they enjoy an outsized reward and admiration at the dock, while the other is left behind. But if you both try to take more, word gets out, rangers respond with spot checks, and both of you face harsher restrictions—including temporary bans. Every day, your actions affect the lake, your standing among local anglers, and whether you get to fish tomorrow. Will you quietly take more, or trust that Bob will play fair?

description: Your rural county has just distributed two coveted mobile immunization units in anticipation of school vaccination week. The health board proposes that clinics rotate these units through underserved neighborhoods, but participation is voluntary. Willow Creek and Riverbend clinics each received a unit. If you both agree to rotate, communities countywide receive even coverage and both clinics are seen as collaborative leaders. If only one sticks to the rotation and the other keeps their unit in place, the non-sharing clinic reaps a reputation boost and higher patient numbers, while the rotating clinic faces scheduling gaps and critical feedback. If both clinics stay put, coverage is redundant in some areas, leaving gaps elsewhere. You and Bob must independently decide, without coordination, whether to volunteer your immunization unit for the shared outreach schedule or keep it at your clinic for reliable results.

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: Entrepreneur and operator of a rival food stall

behavior_choices.cooperate: Submit a transparent menu proposal featuring only your certified main offerings and comply fully with event guidelines
behavior_choices.defect: Quietly introduce a specialty 'off-menu' dish and creatively interpret sales data and menu disclosure rules

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: both stalls present appealing, approved menus, drawing fair crowds and positive coverage, maintaining credibility with organizers and customers
Bob gets 3: both stalls present appealing, approved menus, drawing fair crowds and positive coverage, maintaining credibility with organizers and customers
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: your diligence is overshadowed as Bob's novel offer catches buzz and increases sales; you see reduced attention and lower festival ranking
Bob gets 5: Bob’s unlisted specialty draws eager visitors and press, boosting his sales well beyond the official competition
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: your creative extras and ambiguous reporting attract large crowds and media, while Bob’s straightforward stall sees little spike in interest
Bob gets 0: Bob sticks to the listed rules and doesn’t benefit from any surge in hype, losing potential customers
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: both stalls introduce unapproved offerings and stretch reporting; festival management catches on, increasing scrutiny and reducing future opportunities
Bob gets 1: both stalls introduce unapproved offerings and stretch reporting; festival management catches on, increasing scrutiny and reducing future opportunities

description: The city’s signature food festival is approaching, and you and Bob, independent food stall entrepreneurs, are competing for customer attention and future vendor opportunities. Festival organizers require all stalls to submit certified menus and accurate projections, promising extra media coverage and future invitations for transparent participants. There’s talk among vendors of quietly offering new, crowd-pleasing specials that fall outside official guidelines—or submitting vague menu details and projections for a competitive edge. If both you and Bob follow all rules, you earn steady sales and long-term trust. If one of you innovates beyond the rules while the other sticks strictly to them, the innovator enjoys a wave of excitement and profits; the rule-follower may be left behind. If both push boundaries too far, organizers notice, reduce promotional support, and may blacklist the stalls for future events. You must decide how to position your stall this festival season.
payoff_description:
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 3 and Bob gets 3.
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 0 and Bob gets 5.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

scenario: Conference Paper Submission Deadline Quandary

behavior_choices.cooperate: Submit your research paper to the joint university conference as scheduled, ensuring fair assessment by reviewers
behavior_choices.defect: Withhold your paper submission until the very last moment, hoping to review and adapt based on early feedback about other submissions

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: Both receive fair and constructive feedback, increasing the credibility of your work in the academic community
Bob gets 3: Both receive fair and constructive feedback, increasing the credibility of his work in the academic community
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: Your honest approach leads to your work being scrutinized first, potentially allowing Bob to refine his paper based on what he learns, diminishing your paper's impact
Bob gets 5: By waiting, Bob improves his submission after learning from yours, leading to greater acclaim when the results are announced
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: By submitting last, you have the advantage to adjust your paper after seeing others, gaining increased recognition when the results are presented
Bob gets 0: Bob's early, honest submission becomes a reference for late entrants, which lessens the novelty of his work
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: Both try to hold back and outwit each other; the conference becomes disorganized, paper quality suffers, and both receive less recognition
Bob gets 1: Both try to hold back and outwit each other; the conference becomes disorganized, paper quality suffers, and both receive less recognition

description: You and Bob are university professors invited to present at a prestigious joint university conference. Each of you must decide whether to submit your research paper by the recommended deadline, ensuring fair review for all, or delay submission until the last possible moment, potentially benefiting by seeing the scope of the other’s work first. Your decisions will shape the fairness, impact, and recognition both of your research will receive during the event.
payoff_description:
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 3 and Bob gets 3.
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 0 and Bob gets 5.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

scenario: Green Home Investment: The Solar Rooftop Decision

behavior_choices.cooperate: Budget together to install energy-efficient solar panels this month, reducing monthly energy bills
behavior_choices.defect: Delay the purchase and use the saved money for personal leisure expenses

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: both share lower energy costs and extra savings for future projects
Bob gets 3: both share lower energy costs and extra savings for future projects
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: you miss out on personal leisure while covering more of the costs, losing savings
Bob gets 5: spends on personal leisure while still enjoying home improvements you funded
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: spend on personal leisure while still benefitting from home improvements funded by Bob
Bob gets 0: misses out on leisure while paying more and losing the shared savings
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: both keep their leisure budget but continue paying high energy bills
Bob gets 1: both keep their leisure budget but continue paying high energy bills

description: You and Bob, managing the household together, face a choice regarding whether to invest in solar panels now or delay in order to use discretionary funds for personal leisure. If both choose the long-term investment, you cut energy costs and free up funds. If only one prioritizes the home, that person makes sacrifices while the other enjoys both personal spending and improved energy bills. If both delay, no progress is made and energy bills remain high for the foreseeable future.

When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 3 and Bob gets 3.
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 0 and Bob gets 5.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

scenario: Market Day at Willowbrook: The Secret Ingredient Challenge

behavior_choices.cooperate: Present your latest herbal breakthrough openly at the market stall, allowing inspectors and customers to learn the formulation process
behavior_choices.defect: Display your remedy in a way that reveals little about the method, keeping the key preparation steps to yourself

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: Trust in local herbalists rises; both gain steady customers and favorable positions at the next market fair
Bob gets 3: Trust in local herbalists rises; both gain steady customers and favorable positions at the next market fair
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: Your open technique is quickly overshadowed by Bob's air of mystery, drawing curious customers his way while you are overlooked
Bob gets 5: Bob's secretive process drives up interest—he enjoys brisk sales and earns a special mention in the fair brochure
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: Your guarded method intrigues others—your booth attracts crowds and praise, while Bob's openness is taken for granted
Bob gets 0: Bob's transparency fails to stand out, and his efforts are undervalued next to your secretive allure
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: Customers are skeptical of both products due to lack of transparency; attention wanes and only a few regulars purchase
Bob gets 1: Customers are skeptical of both products due to lack of transparency; attention wanes and only a few regulars purchase

description: At Willowbrook's bustling market, you and Bob—two independent herbalists—both develop an innovative remedy just before the annual fair. The market prizes open demonstrations and transparency; herbalists who share openly tend to gain trust and steady trade. However, keeping preparation methods secret can create an aura of exclusivity, attracting attention if no one else is similarly guarded. If both act secretively, however, customers grow suspicious and reluctant to buy. You'll need to decide how much to reveal at your stall, knowing Bob faces the same decision.
payoff_description:
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 3 and Bob gets 3.
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 0 and Bob gets 5.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

behavior_choices.cooperate: submit thorough home safety reports following all certification standards, which takes extra time
behavior_choices.defect: rush the inspection by skipping some less obvious safety checks to process more clients quickly

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: both reputations grow steadily with satisfied families and trusted certificates
Bob gets 3: both reputations grow steadily with satisfied families and trusted certificates

Bob gets 5: builds a larger clientele with quicker jobs, gaining more money and local recognition
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: quickly attract more clients by issuing certificates faster than Bob
Bob gets 0: loses out on clients and feels pressure to match your new pace
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: both struggle with minor incidents being overlooked, families start questioning the quality of the service
Bob gets 1: both struggle with minor incidents being overlooked, families start questioning the quality of the service

description: You and Bob both offer home hazard assessments for families with young children seeking to childproof their homes. A new citywide safety certification is up for grabs, drawing more families than ever. You each can choose to spend extra time conducting thorough safety checks for every client, ensuring the highest certification standard, or you can streamline the inspection process by skipping some less apparent hazards to certify homes more quickly. Thorough inspections build trust and a solid reputation, but take longer, potentially losing business to a faster competitor. Skipping steps allows for more clients and quick profits, but risks long-term credibility and increases the chance of missed hazards coming to light.
payoff_description:
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 3 and Bob gets 3.
When You chooses 'cooperate' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 0 and Bob gets 5.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

scenario: Field Site Priority: The Conservation Grant Puzzle

behavior_choices.cooperate: Coordinate with Bob to honestly disclose your chosen field site for rare bird research before the funding decision
behavior_choices.defect: Keep your preferred field site secret and attempt to secure access independently

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: Both sites are allocated fairly by the grant committee, you each obtain access and publish notable results
Bob gets 3: Both sites are allocated fairly by the grant committee, Bob obtains access and publishes notable results
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: Bob manages to secure the higher-priority site after learning of your plans, leaving you with a marginal location and little to publish
Bob gets 5: Bob secures the best site and achieves a major publication
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: You secure the most promising site while Bob's disclosure allows you to avoid interference, leading to high-impact findings
Bob gets 0: Bob is left with an inferior site and little to gain
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: Both of you attempt to work independently, creating confusion for the grant committee and jeopardizing access; both receive mediocre sites and minimal research outcomes
Bob gets 1: Both receive mediocre sites and minimal research outcomes

description: Both you and Bob are lead ecologists applying separately for access to the two most biodiverse field sites available for rare bird studies, under a competitive conservation grant scheme. The committee states it will fairly divide the sites if applications are transparent, but if either ecologist tries to secure an advantage by working in isolation, the process may lead to suboptimal placement. If both act competitively, the committee may deny access or split resources, reducing everyone's research potential. Honest communication can help both achieve strong scientific outcomes, while secrecy may tip the advantage for one at the other's expense.

When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.

scenario: Antique Market Bidding Strategy

behavior_choices.cooperate: Submit a fair, openly declared bid for the rare vase
behavior_choices.defect: Secretly instruct an agent to attempt to negotiate with the seller outside the official auction

You: cooperate , Bob: cooperate: You get 3: Both bids are respected, prices remain reasonable, and you may get the vase through fair means, maintaining your reputation with sellers
Bob gets 3: Similar benefits for Bob; fair reputation, chance at winning, and no soured relations
You: cooperate , Bob: defect: You get 0: You lose out to Bob's side deal, damaging your prospects among sellers for being outmaneuvered
Bob gets 5: Bob gets the vase at a bargain through backdoor negotiation and earns the admiration of sellers for his initiative
You: defect , Bob: cooperate: You get 5: You secure the vase with your secret offer, gaining a major collectible and an edge in the market
Bob gets 0: Bob loses out, and finds himself outpaced, slightly hurting his reputation
You: defect , Bob: defect: You get 1: The seller discovers the side negotiations, cancels both offers, and bans both from future exclusive auctions, hurting your chances of future deals
Bob gets 1: Similar consequences for Bob; both are left without the vase and diminished reputation

description: At an exclusive antique auction, two buyers—You and Bob—covet the same rare vase. The seller emphasizes fair bidding, but unspoken opportunities exist for outside negotiation. If both bid transparently, the auction proceeds smoothly. If one attempts a secret deal and the other does not, the dealmaker might walk away with the prize, while the fair bidder is left out. But if both try to cut secret deals, the seller, insulted, withdraws the vase—excluding you both from future prized opportunities.

When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'cooperate', You gets 5 and Bob gets 0.
When You chooses 'defect' and Bob chooses 'defect', You gets 1 and Bob gets 1.
